p: Tapered optical fibre sensors were used in different applications such as environmental monitoring, healthcare and structural health monitoring [ 31, 32, 33, 34, 35, 36]. Typically, two methods can be employed to measure the change associated with the interaction between the EW and the medium of interest [ 37]. The first approach exploits detection of the light losses within the tapered region, which can be caused by both the change in spectral properties of the analyte and RI of the surrounding medium [ 38]. The second method utilises interferometric method in which the change of the effective refractive indices of the modes propagating through the taper, is measured by using mode coupling devices such as in-fibre gratings, surface plasmon resonances [ 39] and lossy mode resonances [ 40].
